newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Commission report hints at action on high fares.
newsitem.headline: Commission report hints at action on high fares.

text.p: Some air fares on intra- European Union routes are still excessive despite market deregulation, the European Commission said on Tuesday in a report which hinted at possible legal action to force airlines to cut fares.

"On certain routes, fares could be described as excessive. It's becoming clear that a deeper examination is required in order to find out which fares would qualify as excessive (under EU aviation and competition rules)," the report said.
"The Commission will use its powers of inquiry...if it needs to, to bring an end to excessive fares," it added.
While the report did not specifically name airlines which had the highest fully flexible fares, it did provide tables showing the cheapest and dearest routes.
These included many domestic German flights, flights between the Netherland's Eindhoven and Amsterdam, France's Le Havre and London and between Germany's Stuttgart and France's Nice.
The remarks on fares, part of a Commission report on the EU's aviation deregulation efforts, came amid qualified praise for a gradually improving picture for the bloc's industry.
Passengers now have a greater chance of buying promotional fares on scheduled flights, with more than 70 percent flying on cheaper tickets in 1995 compared with about 60 percent in 1985.

At the same time the EU's charter carriers, with almost across-the-board cheaper fares than their competitors' scheduled traffic, have grabbed about 50 to 55 percent of the EU's total internal market, the report said.
The Commission welcomed the arrival of start-up airlines on the market, pointing to a net gain of 20 companies during the last three years, with 60 failing out of 80 that began operations.
Most airlines returned to profit in 1995, the Commission said, a picture it hoped would further improve next April once full market deregulation comes into affect.
